description: From Anglo-Norman muniment, Middle French muniment, and their source, Latin mūnīmentum (“fortification, defence”), from mūnīre (“to fortify”).

entries.meaning: (chiefly law) A deed, or other official document kept as proof of ownership or rights or privileges; an archived document. [from 15th c.]
examples: Then, on the order of King Darius, a search was made in Babylonia in the muniment rooms where the archives were kept […]

entries.meaning: (obsolete, in the plural) Things which a person or place is equipped with; effects, furnishings, accoutrements. [15th–19th c.]
(obsolete) Something used as a defence. [16th–19th c.]
